Story: I sat on the edge of the bed, my phone buzzing in my hand. My husband paced the room, his face drawn with worry. He’d just told me about the ultimatum his boss gave him—take on a risky project or risk being sidelined. He needed me, I could see it in his eyes, the way he searched my face for reassurance, for the right words to help him decide. But as he spoke, my phone lit up with a message from my friend: “I can’t believe you said that. I thought you understood me.” My heart clenched. I’d made a careless comment earlier, and now she was hurt, maybe even questioning our friendship. I knew I needed to call her, to explain, to apologize before the misunderstanding grew. But my husband’s voice trembled as he asked, “What do you think I should do?” I felt torn, pulled in two directions by people I loved, both needing me in different ways, both expecting me to be there for them right now. My chest tightened as I stared at my phone, caught between the urge to comfort my husband and the need to make things right with my friend.
